Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Early Career Geoscience Faculty Development Workshop: A partnership between NAGT and NSF
Award.AbstractNarration:
Early career science faculty commonly face significant challenges to establish themselves in a new academic environment, prepare new courses, and begin new research. Providing professional development and networking opportunities can help new science faculty establish the framework for a successful career, which in turn can help to improve undergraduate education and strengthen scientific research and scholarship. The workshops supported by this grant are a continuation of a well-established professional development series designed to help early career faculty flourish in the primary duties of their work, teaching, research, and mentoring. Through a partnership with the National Association of Geoscience Teachers (NAGT), a team of experienced faculty leaders in Earth, atmospheric, marine, and planetary sciences will host three annual workshops at the University of Maryland for approximately seventy-five early career faculty each summer. At each workshop, early career faculty will learn about best practices in teaching, consider successful strategies for maintaining an active research and scholarly practice, and become equipped with resources and tools needed to establish a successful career. The workshop series will emphasize the role of faculty in broadening participation and promoting diversity, equity, and inclusivity in science.

Each workshop will be nationally advertised to invite applicants from all colleges and universities where early career faculty are tasked with teaching, research, and mentoring. The project will provide support for faculty to attend the workshop, especially faculty from two-year colleges. During workshop sessions, the leadership team will model effective pedagogical practices such as active learning techniques, small and large group discussions, problem-solving tasks, and scheduled time for participants to reflect and develop their own action plans. Leaders engage the participants through these sessions along with one-on-one conversations, discipline-specific sessions, and by providing feedback on teaching and research plans. Workshop activities will be evaluated annually and will be modified according to the needs and interests of each cohort of early career faculty. The project leaders will partner with NAGT to produce training curriculum for workshop leaders in methods of promoting diversity, equity, and inclusivity in science through teaching, research, and mentoring. These methods will be infused in workshop sessions and participants will develop personal strategic plans for improving diversity, equity, and inclusivity in science at their home institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative award supported evaluation of the Early Career Geoscience Faculty: Teaching, Research, and Managing Your Career workshop from 2020-2024. The grant supported evaluation of each annual workshop and training curriculum for workshop leaders.

The Early Career Geoscience Faculty: Teaching, Research, and Managing Your Career workshop is a multi-day workshop that aims to provide concrete skills to support early career (pre-tenure) faculty. Since its inception in 1999, the workshop has focused on the three-part nature of academic appointments by dedicating time to topics on teaching, research, and balancing work and life priorities. The four workshops supported by this grant were held:

July 25-29, 2021 (held virtually) with an optional visit to NSF August 3-4 (56 faculty participants);

June 20-24, 2022 at University of Maryland College Park, MD with an optional virtual visit to NSF June 27-28 (39 faculty participants);

June 25-29, 2023 at Macalester College with an optional virtual visit to NSF July 10-11 (54 faculty participants); and

June 23-28, 2024 at Macalester College with an optional virtual visit to NSF (51 faculty participants).

The workshop goals were for participants to:

  • Learn about setting course goals, strategies for active learning, and methods for assessment;
  • Share ideas and strategies for teaching one or more courses;
  • Consider successful strategies for maintaining an active research program and advising/supervising undergraduate and/or graduate research students;
  • Discuss life as an early-career faculty member and explore ways to balance teaching, research, and service responsibilities; and
  • Leave with examples of assignments and activities for various courses, strategies for balancing competing demands, a support network of early career faculty, and a plan for managing your early career as an academic.

Evaluation consisted of survey responses collected via online surveys during and following each annual workshop. Workshop participants consistently reported high satisfaction (averaging above 9.0 on 10 point scale). They reported value in receiving real-time peer feedback on their teaching strategies and scholarship and high value in program sessions focused on strategic planning and proposal review. Each year participants commented on the value of engaging with other early career colleagues with nearly all participants identifying new contacts by name with whom they planned to stay in contact. Ultimately, nearly all participants reported that their confidence to succeed as a faculty member increased after participating in the workshop.

Publication resulting from this award: Beane, R. J., Iverson, E. R., & Macdonald, R. H. (2022). The Early Career Workshop for Geoscience Faculty: One model for multi-institution, discipline-based, holistic STEM faculty development. In S. M. Linder, C. Lee, & K. High (Eds.), Handbook of STEM Faculty Development.

In addition to supporting the Early Career workshop, this award supported training curriculum for workshop leaders. Virtual synchronous workshops were held in 2021 and 2023 and included geoscience faculty who led the Early Career workshop, the Preparing for an Academic Career in Geosciences workshop, and the NAGT Traveling workshop program. A set of webpages (serc.carleton.edu/282917) related to the content of these workshops about facilitating meetings was developed and made publicly available. Additionally, webpages with recordings and associated resource links for the four related webinars that were supported by this award are publicly available. These include: The Climate Survey of the Geosciences (https://nagt.org/248065); Building Inclusive Communities for Research and Scholarly Activities (https://nagt.org/248918); Towards a More Inclusive Geosciences: Teaching Strategies to Support all Students (https://nagt.org/248962); and Promotion, Tenure, and the Value of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion Work (https://nagt.org/249647).
